name: Akshardham Temple
history: A modern architectural marvel, Akshardham is a spiritual-cultural campus dedicated to showcasing Hindu and Indian culture, spirituality, and architecture. The complex displays millennia of traditional Hindu and Indian culture, spirituality, and architecture.

name: Ambaji Temple
history: One of the 18 Maha Shakti Peeths, this sacred temple is where the heart of Goddess Sati is believed to have fallen. The temple is unique as there is no idol; the main object of worship is the sacred Shree Visa Yantra. It's a major pilgrimage center in Gujarat.

name: Amarnath Cave Temple
history: One of the most revered Hindu shrines, the Amarnath Cave is dedicated to Lord Shiva. The cave, situated at an altitude of 3,888m, houses an ice stalagmite that waxes and wanes with the moon's phases, and is considered a 'swayambhu' lingam of Shiva.

name: Arunachaleswarar Temple
history: Representing the element of Fire (Agni Lingam), this grand temple is at the base of the Arunachala hill, considered a manifestation of Shiva. It is a major center for the Shaiva sect and is famous for its massive gopurams and the Karthigai Deepam festival.

name: Badrinath Temple
history: Located on the banks of the Alaknanda River in Uttarakhand, Badrinath Temple is a sacred abode of Lord Vishnu. It is a key site in both the Char Dham and Chota Char Dham pilgrimages. The temple is dedicated to Vishnu's dual form of Badrinarayan, and the main idol is a black Saligram stone believed to be self-manifested.

name: Bhimashankar Temple
history: Located in the Sahyadri hills, this Jyotirlinga shrine is the source of the river Bhima. The temple is built in the Nagara style of architecture and is surrounded by a rich wildlife sanctuary. The legend associated with this temple is of Shiva slaying the demon Tripurasura.

name: Brihadeeswarar Temple
history: Also known as the Big Temple, this stunning example of Dravidian architecture was built by Raja Raja Chola I. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, famed for its massive vimana (tower) and the monolithic Nandi.

name: Chandranath Temple
history: One of the 18 Maha Shakti Peeths, located on top of the Chandranath hill. This is the sacred site where the right arm of Goddess Sati is believed to have fallen. It is a prominent pilgrimage site in Bangladesh.

name: Dwaraka Pitha
history: The western Matha, also known as the Sharada Peetham. It is one of the four cardinal peethams established by Adi Shankaracharya, with the motto 'Tat Tvam Asi' from the Samaveda.

name: Dwarkadhish Temple
history: The Dwarkadhish temple, also known as the Jagat Mandir, is dedicated to Lord Krishna. It is one of the four main pilgrimage sites of the Char Dham. The temple's main shrine is a five-storied structure supported by 72 pillars, believed to be over 2,200 years old. It is situated at the confluence of the Gomti river and the Arabian Sea.

name: Ekambareswarar Temple
history: Representing the element of Earth (Prithvi Lingam), this ancient temple is one of Kanchipuram's most famous landmarks. The Lingam here is believed to be self-manifested (Swayambhu) and is made of sand. The temple has a mango tree said to be 3,500 years old.

name: Gangotri Temple
history: The sacred origin of the River Ganges, this temple is dedicated to Goddess Ganga. It is the second pilgrimage site in the Himalayan Char Dham Yatra. The original temple was built by the Gorkha general Amar Singh Thapa in the early 18th century.

name: Golden Temple (Harmandir Sahib)
history: The holiest Gurdwara and the most important pilgrimage site of Sikhism. It is an open house of worship for all people, from all walks of life and faiths. The temple is surrounded by a sacred pool (sarovar) and has a stunning golden dome.

name: Govardhan Math
history: The eastern Matha established by Adi Shankaracharya. It is associated with the Rigveda and the Mahavakya 'Prajnanam Brahma'. The deity is Jagannath (a form of Vishnu).

name: Grishneshwar Temple
history: The Grishneshwar temple is the last of the twelve Jyotirlingas. It is located near the UNESCO World Heritage site of Ellora Caves. The temple was destroyed and rebuilt several times, with the current structure being restored in the 18th century by Ahilyabai Holkar.

name: Guruvayur Temple
history: A famous Krishna temple, often referred to as 'Bhuloka Vaikunta' (the holy abode of Vishnu on Earth). The central icon is a four-armed standing Krishna carrying the Panchajanya (conch), the Sudarshana Chakra (discus), the Kaumodaki (mace) and a lotus.

name: Harsiddhi Mata Temple
history: One of the 18 Maha Shakti Peeths, Harsiddhi Temple is where the elbow of Goddess Sati is said to have fallen. The temple is famous for its two towering deep-stambhas (lamp pillars) that are lit with hundreds of lamps during Navaratri, creating a spectacular sight.

name: Hinglaj Mata Temple
history: One of the most significant Shakti Peeths, located in a mountain cave on the banks of the Hingol River. It is where Sati's head (Brahmarandhra) is believed to have fallen. It is a revered pilgrimage site for Hindus in Pakistan and beyond.

name: Jagannath Temple, Puri
history: A monumental temple in Puri, dedicated to Lord Jagannath (a form of Vishnu), along with his siblings Balabhadra and Subhadra. It is one of the Char Dham pilgrimage sites. The temple is famous for its annual Ratha Yatra, or chariot festival. The main idols are uniquely carved from neem wood and are ceremoniously replaced every twelve or nineteen years.

name: Jambukeshwarar Temple
history: This temple represents the element of Water (Appu Lingam). The sanctum sanctorum has an underground water stream that perpetually surrounds the Lingam. It is one of the 275 Paadal Petra Sthalams, where the Nayanars have sung praises of the Lord.

name: Jogulamba Temple
history: One of the 18 Maha Shakti Peeths, this is the sacred site where the upper teeth of Goddess Sati are believed to have fallen. The Goddess Jogulamba is a fierce form of Shakti and is depicted seated on a corpse. The temple is part of the Navabrahma temples complex.

name: Jyotirmath
history: The northern Matha, established by Adi Shankaracharya. It is associated with the Atharvaveda and the Mahavakya 'Ayam Atma Brahma'. The temple houses the deity of Badrinarayan and is a significant pilgrimage center in the Himalayas.

name: Jwala Ji Temple
history: A powerful Maha Shakti Peeth where Sati's tongue is said to have fallen. The temple is unique as it does not house an idol, but instead, eternal flames that burn from fissures in the rock, representing the Goddess's fiery form.

name: Kalighat Kali Temple
history: One of the 18 Maha Shakti Peeths in India, where the toes of Sati's right foot are said to have fallen. The temple is a major pilgrimage site for devotees of Goddess Kali, the fierce form of Shakti.

name: Kamakshi Amman Temple
history: A famous Hindu temple dedicated to Kamakshi, one of the forms of the goddess Parvati. The Temple is believed to be one of the three most sacred places of Shakti worship in India.

name: Kamakhya Temple
history: A major Shakti Peeth, this temple is dedicated to the Goddess Kamakhya. It is one of the oldest of the 51 Shakti Peeths. The temple is unique as it worships the yoni (vulva) of the Goddess, symbolized by a rock with a natural spring flowing over it.

name: Kanchi Kamakoti Peetham
history: One of the five Pancha Bootha Sthalams, established by Adi Shankaracharya. This Mutt is dedicated to the Advaita Vedanta tradition and has had an unbroken lineage of pontiffs.

name: Kashi Vishwanath Temple
history: The Kashi Vishwanath Temple, located on the western bank of the holy Ganga in Varanasi, is a cornerstone of Hindu spirituality. As one of the twelve Jyotirlingas, it is an exceptionally powerful site dedicated to Lord Shiva, known here as Vishvanatha, the 'Ruler of the Universe'. The temple complex has been rebuilt multiple times through history, with the current structure dating back to the 18th century, featuring its famous gold-plated spires.

name: Kedarnath Temple
history: Nestled in the Garhwal Himalayas, Kedarnath is one of the most revered Jyotirlingas and a part of the Chota Char Dham Yatra. The temple is believed to have been built by the Pandavas and revived by Adi Shankaracharya. It is accessible only for six months a year due to extreme weather conditions.

name: Konark Sun Temple
history: A 13th-century CE sun temple, attributed to king Narasimhadeva I. It is a monumental representation of the sun god Surya's chariot; its 24 wheels are decorated with symbolic designs and it is led by a team of six horses. A UNESCO World Heritage site.

name: Krishna Janmabhoomi
history: The site is believed to be the birthplace of Lord Krishna. The temple complex includes the Keshavdeva temple, the Garbha Griha shrine and the Bhagavata Bhavan. It's a highly revered pilgrimage site for Vaishnavas.

name: Mahakaleshwar Temple
history: Mahakaleshwar Temple in Ujjain, Madhya Pradesh, stands as one of Hinduism's most sacred shrines, revered as one of the twelve Jyotirlingas of Lord Shiva. It is the only 'dakshinamurti' (south-facing) idol, a unique feature believed to enhance its spiritual potency. The temple is renowned for its Bhasma Aarti, a pre-dawn ritual where the deity is anointed with sacred ash, symbolizing life and death's eternal cycle.

name: Mallikarjuna Temple
history: Situated on the banks of the Krishna River, Mallikarjuna is unique as it is both a Jyotirlinga and a Shakti Peeth. Lord Shiva is worshipped as Mallikarjuna, and his consort Goddess Parvati is revered as Brahmaramba. The temple is located on a hill in the dense Nallamala Forest.

name: Meenakshi Amman Temple
history: An historic Hindu temple located on the southern bank of the Vaigai River in Madurai. It is dedicated to Parvati, known as Meenakshi, and her consort, Shiva, here named Sundareswarar. The temple is famed for its 14 gopurams (gateway towers), painted with bright colors and intricate carvings.

name: Nageshwar Temple
history: Nageshwar Temple is one of the 12 Jyotirlinga shrines mentioned in the Shiva Purana. The temple houses the Nageshwar Jyotirlinga, which is believed to protect devotees from all types of poisons. A large 25-meter tall statue of a seated Lord Shiva is a major attraction of the temple complex.

name: Omkareshwar Temple
history: Located on an island called Mandhata in the Narmada river, the shape of the island is said to be like the Hindu '‡•ê' symbol. This Jyotirlinga shrine is split, with Omkareshwar on one side of the island and Mamleshwar on the other bank of the Narmada.

name: Padmanabhaswamy Temple
history: A magnificent temple with a blend of Chera and Dravidian styles of architecture. It is dedicated to Lord Vishnu, who is enshrined in the 'Anantha Shayanam' posture, the eternal yogic sleep on the serpent Adisheshan. The temple is famous for the vast treasures discovered in its subterranean vaults.

name: Pashupatinath Temple
history: One of the 18 Maha Shakti Peeths, where the knees of Goddess Sati fell. It's a sprawling complex of temples, ashrams, images and inscriptions raised over the centuries along the banks of the sacred Bagmati river. A UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Prem Mandir
history: A modern spiritual complex dedicated to Radha Krishna and Sita Ram. Established by Jagadguru Kripalu Parishat, this temple is an architectural marvel made of Italian marble, showcasing the life of Krishna through intricate carvings and dioramas.

name: Ramanathaswamy Temple
history: This temple is significant as Lord Rama is believed to have prayed to Lord Shiva here to absolve any sins he might have committed during his war against the demon-king Ravana in Sri Lanka. It is a key site in the Char Dham pilgrimage. The temple is famous for its magnificent corridors, which are the longest among all Hindu temples in India.

name: Rameswaram Temple
history: Located on Rameswaram island, this Jyotirlinga is closely associated with the Ramayana. It is believed that Lord Rama worshipped Shiva here to atone for the sin of killing Ravana, a Brahmin. The temple is renowned for its magnificent corridors and 22 holy water tanks (tirthas).

name: Ranakpur Jain Temple
history: A stunning temple dedicated to Tirthankara Rishabhanatha. It is one of the most important pilgrimage sites of Jainism. The temple is known for its intricate carvings and 1,444 marble pillars, each carved differently.

name: Shankari Devi Temple
history: One of the 18 Maha Shakti Peeths, located in the port city of Trincomalee. The original temple was destroyed by the Portuguese in the 17th century, but it has since been restored. It is where the groin of Sati is believed to have fallen.

name: Somnath Temple
history: The Somnath Temple, located on the western coast of Gujarat, is traditionally considered the first of the twelve Jyotirlinga shrines of Lord Shiva. It has been destroyed and rebuilt numerous times throughout history, standing today as a symbol of eternal faith and resilience. Its seaside location adds to its profound spiritual ambiance.

name: Srikalahasti Temple
history: Representing the element of Air (Vayu Lingam), this temple is famous for its Vayu linga, which is one of the Panchabhoota Sthalams. An interesting feature is a lamp inside the inner sanctum that constantly flickers despite the lack of air movement.

name: Thillai Nataraja Temple, Chidambaram
history: Representing the element of Ether/Sky (Akasha Lingam), this temple is dedicated to Shiva as the cosmic dancer, Nataraja. The sanctum is unique, representing the 'Chidambara Rahasyam' (Secret of Chidambaram), which signifies formless worship.

name: Trimbakeshwar Temple
history: Located at the source of the Godavari river, Trimbakeshwar is unique because its Jyotirlinga has three faces embodying Lord Brahma, Lord Vishnu, and Lord Shiva. The linga is in a depression on the floor of the sanctum and is constantly bathed by water flowing from the Godavari.

name: Vaishno Devi Temple
history: A temple dedicated to the Hindu Goddess, located in the Trikuta Mountains. The shrine is located in a cave and the Goddess is symbolized in the form of three natural rock formations, the Pindies. It is one of the most visited pilgrimage sites in India.

name: Vaidyanath Temple
history: Vaidyanath Jyotirlinga temple, also known as Baba Baidyanath Dham, is one of the twelve Jyotirlingas. It is also a Shakti Peeth, where the heart of Sati fell, making it a place of dual reverence. Devotees carry water from the Ganges to offer to the lingam, a pilgrimage known as the Kanwar Yatra.

name: Vindhyachal Temple
history: Vindhyavasini Devi Temple is a major Hindu pilgrimage site, considered a Shakti Peeth. The goddess is worshipped in the form of Vindhyavasini, who is believed to be the instant bestower of benediction.

name: Yamunotri Temple
history: Situated in the western region of Garhwal Himalayas, this temple is dedicated to the Goddess Yamuna and marks the source of the Yamuna River. It is the first pilgrimage stop in the Himalayan Char Dham circuit.
